article-doc.publication: The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition

p.link: GM recalled another 8.5 million vehicles, including more than eight million for ignition-switch defects, and said it knew of three deaths in accidents involving the affected cars.
The auto maker outlined a compensation plan for death and injury claims tied to certain recalled vehicles.
BNP agreed to pay nearly $9 billion and plead guilty to crimes for violating U.S. sanctions, accepting a temporary dollar-clearing ban.
Trian has built a stake in Bank of New York Mellon valued at $1.05 billion and plans to discuss ways to create shareholder value.
A pending home sales index rose 6.1% in May, further evidence that the U.S. housing recovery began to regain its footing this spring.
Employers are remaining frugal when it comes to office space, even as U.S. employment pushes past its prerecession levels.
The Dow slipped 25.24 points, or 0.1%, to 16826.60. The blue chips finished the second quarter up 2.2%.
Puerto Rico's power authority bonds continued to sink on concerns the agency is running out of cash.
Argentina said it will send a delegation to meet with a mediator as it tries to resolve a dispute with creditors.
Prosecutors in the U.K. said they would retry former News Corp editor Andy Coulson for alleged bribery.
